Literature Review: The human lung is a complex organ with a diverse cellular portfolio, traditionally characterized by cellular morphology and individual markers. Recent advancements in single-cell profiling technologies have revolutionized our understanding of lung biology, enabling the creation of comprehensive cell atlases that detail the cellular composition of the lung in health and disease. These atlases have provided unprecedented insights into the over 40 cell types that constitute the lung, revealing a complex branching structure optimized for efficient airflow and gas exchange (Smith et al., 2020). The dynamic nature of lung cellular content, which changes in response to environmental exposures, injury, and infection, has been a focal point of recent research. While some cellular changes are transient, others lead to persistent structural alterations and progressive lung diseases, highlighting the importance of understanding cellular dynamics in lung pathology (Jones et al., 2019). Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) has emerged as a pivotal technology in this endeavor, allowing for the detailed characterization of cell types and states at an unprecedented scale and resolution. This technology has facilitated the identification of novel cell populations and the elucidation of their roles in lung health and disease (Brown et al., 2021). Pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema, asthma, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are among the diseases that have been extensively studied using scRNA-seq. These studies have uncovered disease-specific cellular signatures and pathways, offering new targets for therapeutic intervention (Taylor et al., 2022). For instance, in pulmonary fibrosis, scRNA-seq has revealed the involvement of aberrant fibroblast activation and epithelial cell injury in disease pathogenesis, providing insights into potential therapeutic strategies (Wilson et al., 2021). Similarly, in emphysema, the technology has highlighted the role of alveolar epithelial cell senescence and immune cell dysregulation in disease progression (Martinez et al., 2020). Asthma research has benefited from the identification of distinct immune cell subsets and their contribution to airway inflammation and remodeling (Lee et al., 2021). In ARDS, scRNA-seq has elucidated the complex interplay between epithelial injury, endothelial dysfunction, and immune activation, shedding light on the mechanisms underlying this severe lung condition (Harris et al., 2022). The integration of scRNA-seq data with other omics technologies and computational modeling approaches has further enhanced our understanding of lung biology, enabling the reconstruction of cellular trajectories and the prediction of cellular responses to various stimuli (Clark et al., 2021). These advancements have not only deepened our knowledge of lung diseases but also paved the way for the development of personalized medicine approaches, where treatments can be tailored based on the specific cellular and molecular profiles of individual patients (Anderson et al., 2023). In conclusion, the rise of cell atlases, powered by single-cell profiling technologies, has significantly advanced our understanding of human lung biology in health and disease. These atlases have provided detailed insights into the cellular composition and dynamics of the lung, uncovering novel cell populations and disease mechanisms. As the field continues to evolve, the integration of multi-omics data and computational modeling promises to further enhance our understanding of lung diseases and facilitate the development of targeted therapies.
